heroContent.title: Summary
heroContent.descTitle: Island Party Music Festival is a philanthropy event hosted by the men of Beta Upsilon Chi raising money for Living Water International and The Bridge Ministries. I was a member of this Christian Fraternity and had the opportunity to further solidify a robust brand. Below you will find the transformation between the 2018 and 2019 events.

sectionContent.title: Lets take a look at the past: Island Party 2018.
sectionContent.descTitle: My primary responsibility as the graphic designer in 2018 was to establish a direction for the social media graphics package. Below are some samples of what we ended up choosing.

sectionContent.title: A colorful explosion of gratitude.
sectionContent.descTitle: For Island Party 2019, I was the Marketing Director / Lead Graphic Designer. We wanted the marketing material to be eye-catching and we came up with two main focuses: revisiting the color scheme and introduce motion graphics.

sectionContent.title: Pictures, pictures, and more pictures.
sectionContent.descTitle: We lacked a photo catalog from past events, so starting in 2018 we focused on getting a team of photographers. Below are select shots taken by me at our preliminary — Battle of the Bands — and Island Party Music Festival.

heroContent.descTitle: As a family of companies, Puritan Financial wants to highlight their top performing employees in a unique way through a monthly video update. I was tasked to perform a redesign of their monthly video content by introducing improved design and motion graphics.

sectionContent.title: Highlight Video
sectionContent.descTitle: This is a description of the design and motion before.

sectionContent.title: After
sectionContent.descTitle: This is a boosted professional look to compliment the employee highlights.

heroContent.title: Summary
heroContent.descTitle: Re-imagine the current NASA app. Build the experience from the icon through multiple key pages.

heroContent.title: Challenge
heroContent.descTitle: NASA prides itself on technologic innovations, yet their mobile app does not extend that notion.

sectionContent.title: Discovery
sectionContent.descTitle: After using the current app for NASA I noticed that it lacks a cohesive navigation experience. There are several localized menus that requires the user to switch focus. Additionally, there does not seem to be a design language which results in sporadic layouts from page-to-page.

sectionContent.title: Explorations
sectionContent.descTitle: There are a handful of key elements and pages that I focused on to showcase an improved navigation style.

sectionContent.title: Iterations
sectionContent.descTitle: A card based system was a logical way to present the information and to keep a consistent design language with the dynamic content such as the news or live videos.

sectionContent.title: Final Outcome
sectionContent.descTitle: The vision of NASA is to "reach new heights and reveal the unknown for the benefit of mankind." As a result, I redesigned the NASA mobile app with the goal of making the content a visual extension of what they stand for. This was achieved by making the content readily accessible with a card based system and a streamlined navigation system.

additionalContent.title: Painpoints of current design.
additionalContent.description:
- Section titles are hidden or too small
- Elements are crammed into spaces or forced to the edges
- Large bodies of text
- Lack of a design language
- Feels like a website squeezed into a mobile app

additionalContent.title: Focused on the planet page
additionalContent.description:
I used the planets page as the main focus to demonstrate the app functionality in 3 levels:

1. Planet landing page provides a list of all planets
2. Planet home page gives a brief insight into basic statistics about a particular planet
3. More info tab provides a detailed description of the planet

additionalContent.title: Presenting the content in a meaningful way
additionalContent.description:
- The home page acts as a dashboard that prioritizes the most frequently updated sections.
- On the NASA app, there was an interactive solar system. I thought that idea would compliment a list of the planets too.
- An icon is the first interaction a user has with an app. Making the design simple enough while retaining the NASA branding was the initial goal.

heroContent.title: Summary
heroContent.descTitle: The idea behind the project was to combine personal recommendations with the utility of a professional networking app. Originally people would use LinkedIn purely as a utility tool: meet someone in person, connect with them on the app, and see their work history. There were not cluttered news feeds, meaningless notifications, or random connection requests. The goal was to cut through the noise of typical social media chatter to build a more organic professional network.

heroContent.title: High-level Goals
heroContent.descTitle:
• 1. Create an experience that encourages authentic conversations.
  • 2. Give people more opportunities to connect to the right people.
  • 3. Centralize information to avoid lost time browsing the app.

sectionContent.title: Explorations
sectionContent.descTitle: By exploring different iterations, we focused on allowing a user to freely explore the app by compartmentalizing areas to provide relevant interactions.

sectionContent.title: Discovery
sectionContent.descTitle: The assumptions we used were based on personal experiences, online research, and personal conversations. We identified that people found it difficult to transition career paths due to a lack of personal connections in the desired industry. Additionally, this feeling exists outside of a professional setting.

sectionContent.title: Final Outcome
sectionContent.descTitle: As a result, we designed Warm Intro for two specific cases: ease of access and authenticity. By combining intelligent suggestions and human actions, people will be able to expand their network in a purposeful way.

additionalContent.title: User-flow
additionalContent.description: The main focus was to show the various ways someone could begin finding connections and kickstarting conversations.

additionalContent.title: Inspiration
additionalContent.description: As we reflected on common frustrations – impersonal connections, empty notifications, and cluttered home pages — we identified that information needed to be readily accessible. Many component ideas came from e-commerce platforms, AI meeting software, and intriguing onboarding elements.

additionalContent.title: Home
additionalContent.description: The home section is the heart of the app that acts as a dashboard. This evolved to where all major actions - reviewing requests, browsing posts, and browsing suggested connections - took place.

additionalContent.title: Network and Groups
additionalContent.description: Initially we decided to combine these two areas of the app. However, we discovered that people may be getting on the app to accomplish a specific task. So, combining multple sections became confusing quick.

additionalContent.title: Messaging
additionalContent.description: The messaging area was a section we did not need to stray away from established formats. This became the area where users could review introduction requests and track, new or existing conversations.

additionalContent.title: Intro Request and Posting
additionalContent.description: The first couple of screens are from the view of a mutual connection that believes Person 1's objective aligns with Person 2's objective. Posting is an opportunity for a user to explore a specified objective.

additionalContent.title: Posting
additionalContent.description: The ability to post is available on most screens. A user can choose to post to their entire network or in a specific group.

additionalContent.title: Browse Posts
additionalContent.description: Users are able to explore relevant activity from their 1st degree network, but have the ability to see posts from their entire network. The post format gives all details at a glance to make an informed decision.

additionalContent.title: Review Requests
additionalContent.description: Reviewing requests is a temporary section in the messaging tab. This is where a mutual connection can choose to accept and decline an introduction request.

additionalContent.title: Review Messages
additionalContent.description: Three main sections of messages: 1. review introduction requests 2. new conversations and 3. existing conversations. In each conversation, the origin of how the two people met is added.

additionalContent.title: Browse Suggested Connections
additionalContent.description: Based on the user's objectives, suggested connections will be populated with people that have similar or complementary objectives. If a person is highlighted as a confirmed 1st degree connection, through a linked contact list, a user can choose to immediately connect with them.

additionalContent.title: Review Groups
additionalContent.description: Groups retain the same format as the network page, but provide information specific to a particular group. Since groups are a common area for members, direct messaging is made available.
